conclusion: Analyzing whether the gas absorbs or releases heat during the A→B process in the Stirling cycle.
The process moves from point A to point B.
The volume increases (moving right on the V-axis).
The pressure decreases (moving down on the P-axis).
The problem states this is an isothermal process (constant temperature).
Applying the First Law of Thermodynamics: ΔU = Q - W.
For an ideal gas in an isothermal process: ΔU = 0 (internal energy depends only on temperature for an ideal gas).
W = ∫P·dV (work done by the system during expansion).
Since the gas is expanding (V increases), the system is doing positive work (W > 0).
Rearranging the First Law for this isothermal process: Q = ΔU + W = 0 + W = W.
Since W is positive (the gas is expanding and doing work on the surroundings), Q must also be positive.
During the isothermal expansion from A to B, the gas expands, which would naturally cause cooling.
Since the temperature remains constant (isothermal process), heat must be transferred to the gas to maintain its temperature.
This heat compensates for the energy the gas loses by doing work during expansion.
The gas absorbs heat when moving from state A to state B in the Stirling cycle.
